keyTakeAways: Christopher Moynihan, a convicted participant in the January 6 Capitol attack, was arrested for threatening to kill Democratic House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries.
Moynihan was previously sentenced to nearly two years in prison for obstructing an official proceeding and disorderly conduct during the Capitol riot.
President Donald Trump pardoned Moynihan earlier in 2025 as part of a broader pardon of January 6 defendants.
Moynihan made threatening text messages to an anonymous source stating he would kill Jeffries 'for the future' and 'even if he is hated he must be eliminated'.
New York State Police indicated concerns about Moynihan's recent drug abuse and increased homicidal ideations.
A New York judge ruled that Moynihan will remain in prison pending a hearing on whether he can be released on bail for the terroristic threat charge.
Jeffries criticized Trump's blanket pardon, emphasizing that threats of violence will not deter democratic participation.
Moynihan's prior legal history includes opiate addiction and misdemeanor convictions linked to substance use, with attorneys requesting mental health and addiction treatment during incarceration.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Christopher Moynihan, a convicted participant in the January 6 Capitol attack, was arrested for threatening to kill U.S. Representative Hakeem Jeffries, a Democratic House Minority Leader. Despite being pardoned by President Donald Trump earlier in 2025, Moynihan remains in prison pending a hearing on a terroristic threat charge, having allegedly stated in a text message that he would kill Jeffries 'for the future.' Law enforcement has raised concerns about Moynihan’s recent drug use and homicidal ideations. Jeffries criticized Trump’s blanket pardon, asserting that threats of violence do not diminish the resolve of democratic leaders. The incident reflects broader national anxiety over political violence, especially in light of recent assassinations like that of Charlie Kirk.
